column15: after breaking away from Shrewsbury Township. It was renamed "Tinton Falls" in 1975
column16: to avoid postal errors. The name came from Lewis Morris's plantation
column18: which employed free white workers and slaves. The borough is home to the highest waterfall on New Jersey's coastal plain.

column1: The area that is now known as Tinton Falls was originally settled in the late 1600s
column2: probably beginning with the initial land purchases from the Lenni Lenape Native Americans in 1664. Water power and iron ore were likely the incentives that encouraged settlement: shortly after [the land was purchased]
column3: a man by the name of James Grover had an ironworks built along the river.  Grover was likely the founder of the community
column6: was named "New Shrewsbury". At this time
column7: the waterfall was known to be about 30 feet (9.1 m) high; erosion and the destruction of the dam near the ironworks have led to its diminishment.

column1: Grover's ironworks was the central fixture of the community
column2: and it was one of the oldest built in the country
column3: predated only by buildings in Jamestown and Massachusetts. In 1675
column4: a half-interest in the ironworks company was purchased by Colonel Lewis Morris
column6: 540 acres (14.3 km2) along the Shrewsbury River].  Morris also obtained land owned by Bartholomew Applegate
column7: who had built a corn mill on the other side of the river. Morris
column8: who procured the land for iron mining
column10: after his family lands in Monmouthshire, England. Tintern Abbey, located in Monmouthshire, Wales, is often accepted as the namesake of Tinton Falls.  In 1691, Colonel Morris died, leaving the ironworks and Tinton Manor (a corruption of Tintern Manor") to his nephew of the same name.  By 1714
column11: the ironworks had become less profitable
column12: but mention of a Tinton Falls ironworks can be found as late as 1844. Morris brought in dozens of African slaves to mine the ore resulting in the nickname the "Iron Plantation"
column13: with the highest number of slaves being in Tinton Falls at that time in the colony of New Jersey
column14: though in the mid-18th century it had the largest number of emancipated slaves in the 13 colonies
column15: as residents followed the preaching of abolitionist John Woolman.

column2: Tinton Manor and the surrounding lands were defined as part of Shrewsbury Township.  At this time
column3: Shrewsbury included all of the land in eastern Monmouth County
column4: but saw the departure of a large number of new municipalities over the years
column5: including the borough of Shrewsbury in 1926. In July 1950
column6: Tinton Falls and Wayside left Shrewsbury Twp.
column7: renaming themselves the Borough of New Shrewsbury.  To avoid postal confusion and mix-ups with the surrounding borough and township of Shrewsbury
column8: the residents of New Shrewsbury voted to rename the community as "The Borough of Tinton Falls" in 1975.

column1: The Borough of Tinton Falls operates under the Faulkner Act
column2: formally known as the Optional Municipal Charter Law
column3: using the Mayor-Council form of municipal government (Plan 6)
column4: implemented by direct petition as of July 1
column5: 1985. The borough is one of 71 municipalities (of the 565) statewide governed under this form. The governing body is comprised of the Mayor and the Borough Council. The Mayor is the chief executive officer of the Borough and is directly elected for a four-year term of office. The Borough Council is the legislative body
column6: comprised of five members elected at-large on a non-partisan basis for four-year terms on a staggered basis
column7: with either two or three seats up for election every other year as part of the November general election
column8: with the mayoral seat up for vote at the same time that two council seats are being chosen by voters. A business administrator reports to
column9: and may act on behalf of the Mayor
column10: in the Mayor's absence. The Borough Council voted in May 2010 to shift its elections from May to the November general election
column11: as part of an effort to increase participation of voters and to cut costs associated with the May elections
column13: 000 during the first decade after the change was implemented in the November 2011 vote.As of 2020

column20: ran on a platform of lowering taxes and improving transparency. Members of the Borough Council are Council President Tracy A. Buckley (2023)

column1: Public school students in kindergarten through eighth grade attend the three schools in the Tinton Falls School District
column2: together with students from the neighboring community of Shrewsbury Township and the dependent children of military families based at Naval Weapons Station Earle. All three of the district's schools are located in Tinton Falls. Shrewsbury Township is represented with one seat out of nine on the district's board of education. As of the 2018–19 school year
column3: the district
column6: 447 students and 150.1 classroom teachers (on an FTE basis)
column7: for a student–teacher ratio of 9.6:1. Schools in the district (with 2018–19 enrollment data from the National Center for Education Statistics) are
